Submodules¶

traceHMM.model module¶

The TraceModel class and a simulator for Markov chains.

class traceHMM.model.TraceModel(X: ~numpy.ndarray, Pm: ~numpy.ndarray, dist_params: tuple[dict, ...], dist_type=<scipy.stats._continuous_distns.norm_gen object>, update_dist_params: list = None)¶

Bases: object

Modified hidden Markov model to infer chromatin loops.

Parameters:

  • X ((N, T, D) np.ndarray) – Input value (of D dimension) of N trajectories over T time points.

  • Pm ((S, S) np.ndarray) – Initial transition matrix. Entries with negative values will be updated. Other entries with nonnegative values will not be updated and will be the same after fitting.

  • dist_params (tuple[dict, ...]) – Tuple of length S. Each element is a dictionary specifying the parameters of the distribution at each state.

  • dist_type (distribution class, optional) – A distribution class that has a pdf method, by default stats.norm. dist_params will be passed in as keyword arguments.

  • update_dist_params (list, optional) – A list of parameters to update for the distributions at each state, by default None. If update_dist_params is not None, then the distribution class supplied must have a mle method that returns a dictionary with keys containing update_dist_params.

property N: int¶

Number of trajectories in X.

property P: ndarray¶

Transition probability matrix.

property S: int¶

Number of states.

property T: int¶

Number of time points in X.

property convergence: list¶

The mean absolute difference between the updated transition matrix and the transition matrix from the last iteration.

decode(X: ndarray = None) → ndarray¶

Predict the looping status of the input data using the fitted model. Has to be run after fit.

Parameters:

X ((N', T', D) np.ndarray, optional) – New chromatin trace to predict looping status, by default None. If None is passed, will return the predicted loop status of the input used to train the model.

Returns:

Same shape as X. Contains the prediction result.

Return type:

np.ndarray

density(state: int | ndarray, x: ndarray) → int | ndarray¶

Calculates the probability of given observation(s) at state(s).

Parameters:

  • state (int | np.ndarray) – A single state or an array of states to evaluate x.

  • x ((..., D) np.ndarray) – Observations. Can be (T, D), which specifies the observations at T time points, or (N, T, D), which specifies the observations at T time points of N observations.

Returns:

Probability of observing x at state(s). Will broadcast.

Return type:

int | np.ndarray

fit(max_iter: int = 100, cutoff: float = 0.0001)¶

Fit the TraceModel using the input data.

Parameters:

  • max_iter (int, optional) – Maximum number of iterations, by default 100

  • cutoff (float, optional) – Criterion to terminate iterations, by default 1e-4. Fitting will end if the mean absolute difference of transition matrix is below this cutoff.

property lklhd: list¶

A list of the log-likelihood of the model at each iteration.

property loc_err: ndarray¶

The estimated localization error in nm/um. Available only if update_dist_params contains “err”.

property mu: ndarray¶

Initial distribution. Initialized to be uniform in each state.

class traceHMM.model.TraceSimulator(P: ~numpy.ndarray, mu: ~numpy.ndarray, dist_params: tuple[dict, ...], dist_type=<scipy.stats._continuous_distns.norm_gen object>, random_state=None)¶

Bases: object

Simulate chromatin traces based on a Markov chain.

Parameters:

  • P ((S, S) np.ndarray) – The transition probability of the Markov chain.

  • mu – The initial distribution.

  • dist_params (tuple[dict, ...]) – Tuple of length S. Each element is a dictionary specifying the parameters of the distribution at each state.

  • dist_type (_type_, optional) – A distribution class that has a rvs method, by default stats.norm. dist_params will be passed in as keyword arguments.

property P: ndarray¶

Transition probability matrix.

mask_by_markov_chain(X: ndarray, p_obs: float, a: float = 0.8) → ndarray¶

Mask spatial distance by a two-state Markov chain. This is inspired by the fact that missing observations are typically continuous in real imaging data.

Parameters:

  • X ((..., T, D) np.ndarray) – Input spatial distance to be masked.

  • p_obs (float) – The observed probability.

  • a (float, optional) – P(stay unobserved), by default 0.8. Needed as otherwise the linear system resulting from stationary distribution has infinite solutions.

Returns:

Same shape as X with missing observations filled by NaN.

Return type:

(…, T) np.ndarray

static mask_spatial_distance(self, X: ndarray, p_obs: float) → ndarray¶

Mask spatial distance uniformly at random to simulate the missing data problem observed in real imaging data.

Parameters:

  • X ((..., T, D) np.ndarray) – Input spatial distance to be masked.

  • p_obs (float) – The observed probability.

Returns:

Same shape as X with missing observations filled by NaN.

Return type:

(…, T) np.ndarray

property mu: ndarray¶

Initial distribution. Initialized to be uniform in each state.

simulate_multiple_traces(T: int, N: int) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray]¶

Simulate multiple traces based on the input transition matrix and initial distribution.

Parameters:

  • T (int) – Number of time points to generate.

  • N (int) – Number of traces to generate.

Returns:

The first element is the true loop status of the trace. The second element is the spatial distance generated at each time point.

Return type:

tuple[(N, T) np.ndarray, (N, T) np.ndarray]

simulate_single_trace(T: int) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray]¶

Simulate a single trace based on the input transition matrix and initial distribution.

Parameters:

T (int) – Number of time points to generate.

Returns:

The first element is the true loop status of the trace. The second element is the spatial distance generated at each time point.

Return type:

tuple[(T) np.ndarray, (T, D) np.ndarray]

class traceHMM.model.multivariate_chisq¶

Bases: object

Multivariate independent chi-square distribution.

pdf(scales: ndarray) → float | ndarray¶

Independent scaled Chi-squared distributions each with a degree of freedom of one.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Single observations or observations in ndarrays. The last axis has the same dimension as the length of scales.

  • scales (np.ndarray) – The scale of each Chi-squared distribution. Assume the observation is $Y^2$, where $Y = s X$ with $X ~ N(0, 1)$. The scale is $s^2$.

Returns:

The probability density of the observations.

Return type:

float|np.ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If the shape of the last axis of X does not match scales.

class traceHMM.model.multivariate_normal¶

Bases: object

Multivariate normal distribution with measurement errors.

mle() → dict¶

Calculate the updated measurement errors.

Parameters:

tm (TraceModel) – Model that has gone through at least one iteration so that u and v are available.

Returns:

A dictionary with the new measurement errors under the key err. The value is a list of measurement error matrix at each state.

Return type:

dict

pdf(cov: ndarray, err: ndarray = None, **kwargs) → ndarray¶

PDF of multivariate normal distribution with measurement errors. The measurement errors are added to the diagonal of the covariance matrix.

Parameters:

  • X ((..., D) np.ndarray) – Observed values to evaluate the PDF.

  • cov ((D, D) np.ndarray) – The base covariance.

  • err ((D, D) np.ndarray, optional) – The measurement errors to add, by default None, treat as zeros.

Returns:

PDF computed.

Return type:

np.ndarray

rvs(size: tuple[int, ...], err: ndarray = None, **kwargs) → ndarray¶

Generate random samples based on the covariance and measurement errors specified.

Parameters:

  • cov ((D, D) np.ndarray) – The base covariance.

  • size (tuple[int,...]) – Generated sample shape. Inputted to scipy’s rvs function.

  • err ((D, D) np.ndarray, optional) – The measurement errors to add, by default None, treat as zeros.

Returns:

Generated random samples of shape (size, D).

Return type:

np.ndarray

traceHMM.update module¶

traceHMM.update.calculate_v(arg0: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg1: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg2: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg3: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg4: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg5: int, arg6: int, arg7: int) → numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64]¶

Calculate conditional expectation (v).

traceHMM.update.scaled_backward(arg0: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg1: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg2: int, arg3: int, arg4: int) → numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64]¶

Scaled backward algorithm.

traceHMM.update.scaled_forward(arg0: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg1: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg2: numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], arg3: int, arg4: int, arg5: int) → numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64]¶
